entry.title: First Steps with Joule Skill (Advanced): Request Badges for Multiple Users with Automation
entry.content:
It has been about three months since Joule Studio was released.
Several tutorials are already available on SAP Tutorials, and the community is slowly getting more active.  And, I think many people still wonder: ‚ÄúWhat can we really do with Joule Studio?‚Äù„ÄÇ

One of the tutorials is ‚ÄúBuild Your First Joule Skill in Joule Studio.‚Äù In this tutorial, you create two Actions, Action to read data from an S/4 mock system and Action to create a badge. Then you use these Actions in a Joule Skill.

In this tutorial, you will create an action project for accessing business partner information from an OData service representing an SAP system. You will also create an action project for creating a badge request via an OData service representing a third-party system.

This tutorial is very good and easy to learn how to make Joule Skill. However, one of my colleagues asked me a question:

‚ÄúWhat if we want to send badge requests for multiple users at once?‚Äù

With the tutorial as it is, you need to send a request to Joule one user at a time.

So in this blog, we will change the scenario and send badge requests for multiple users in one go.

There is one problem. In Joule Skill, we do not have loop control function like "Go to Step" in Process, "forEach" in Automation. Because of this, it is difficult to call Business Partner GET and Badge Create POST again and again inside Joule Skill only.

To solve this, we will use Automation inside Joule Skill. This is the final flow:

„ÄÄ

 

Step1 - Create a Skeleton Joule Skill

A Joule Skill can call Automaton (or Process). In this scenario, we will send a list of Business Partner Ids from the Joule Skill to the Automation. However, in the Joule Skill, the input parameter on trigger phase does not have a data type setting. It is treated as String only.

So, on the Joule side, Joule will enter IDs as one comma-separated string like "AAAA, BBBB". And, inside the Automation, we will convert this String to a List of String. In the Joule Skill, we define the input parameter like:

  • Inputs Name: BusinessPartnerList
  •  Description: a list of BusinessPartner ID like "AAAA, BBBB"

(In the original tutorial, there are some other input parameters. To keep this blog simple, I will not use them here.)

 

Step2 - Create the Automation

Next, we create an Automation. Leave the Joule Skill editor, and go to SAP Build Lobby to create a new Automation project.

If you have not se up the Desktop Agent yet, plz follow this tutorial:
Install and Set Up Desktop Agent 3

At the beginning of the Automation, we use a Custom Script to convert the input String to a List of String. The image is like the following Javascript:

function parseIds(rawIds) {
  if (typeof rawIds !== "string") {
    throw new Error("rawIds must be a string like 'AAA, BBBB'.");
  }

  const ids = rawIds
    .split(",")
    .map(s => s.trim())
    .filter(Boolean);

  if (ids.length === 0) {
    throw new Error("No valid IDs found. Expected something like 'AAA, BBBB'.");
  }

  return ids;
}

With this, we can use forEach in the next step and process each ID one by one.

Next, open Project Properties(top-right gear icon), and select Manage Dependencies -> Add an Action Project Dependency. Here, add the two Action Projects from the original tutorial, Business Partner GET and Badge Create POST. 

Now we build the flow like this:

  1. Convert the input String to a List by the "String to List" Custom Script
  2. Use forEach to take one ID at a time
  3. Call the Action Get data from BusinessPartner API
  4. Call the Action Create Badge using the result

Finally, in Project Properties -> Attributes, connect the Agent attribute that you created when you set up the Agent.

When everything is ready, click Release -> Deploy. Then, to use this Automation from Joule Skill, go to the Lobby, open the correct version and click Publish to Library.

 

3. Use the Automation inside the Joule Skill

Go back to your Joule Skill, and add a Run Automation step. First, click Browse All Automations and select the Automation you just created.

Next, map the Joule Skill input parameter Business PartnerList to the Automation input.

After that, add a Send Message node in the next step. 

When the flow is ready, click Release -> Deploy for the Joule Skill as well.

 

4. Test the scenario

As I mentioned before, an Automation needs an Agent (and in the correct, "Agent" is not an AI Agent üòÄ). When we run an Automation from inside a Joule Skill, we must tell Joule which Agent to use.

Open Control Tower -> Environments, and go to the environment where your Automation and Joule Skill are deployed. In Agent Management, add the target Agent to that environment.

On your local PC, open the Desktop Agent settings and check that Agent Mode is Unattended.

In the environment screen, you will see a tab named ‚ÄúJoule‚Äù on the far right. Check the version of the Joule Skill you created, and click Launch to open Joule.

Now, try to send a prompt to test the Skill.

You can see that a badge request is created for each ID!!

Internally, the Automation is just running a forEach loop, so the same design works for both a single request and multiple requests in one run. In the future, if Joule Skills support file upload, we may also be able to read IDs from a file and send a large number of badge requests in bulk.

 

Conclusion

What do you think? With this approach, we can extend a Joule Skill by using our existing knowledge of SAP Build Process Automation. The way we design the Automation is almost the same as in other SBPA use cases. We simply call it from Joule.

On the other hand, there are still some gaps:

  • Joule Skill does not have flexible flow control like Go to Step
  • We cannot directly map Automation output to Joule Skill variables yet (SAP Help says there is an Output tab, but in my current environment I cannot see it.) 

Even with these limits, combining Joule Studio and SBPA already gives us many options. I am very excited to see how Joule Studio will grow in future updates!!!!

 

The CoE Japan team runs PoCs and scenario validations not only for Joule Studio, but also for many other SAP products. Through technical validations, architecture discussions, and sharing best practices, we support our customers and partners in getting more value from SAP from a technical point of view.

If you are thinking: ‚ÄúCan we do something like this with Joule or SAP Build?‚Äù please feel free to contact the CoE Japan team.

entry.title: Setting Up Joule Studio for All Partner Flows and Entitlement Levels
entry.content:
This blog was authored by Joule Studio Product Managers: Charan Ravikumar and Maria Kondratyeva

 

Setting Up Joule Studio for All Partner Flows and Entitlement Levels

Joule Studio, the latest capability in SAP Build, empowers developers to extend SAP's AI copilot with custom Joule skills and powerful Joule agents tailored to your unique business needs. These capabilities extend Joule, orchestrate complex cross-functional workflows, and unlock new levels of enterprise efficiency.

However, we recognize that the partner landscape, with its mix of TDD, PAYG, and subscription accounts, introduces unique complexities. Many of you have asked the essential question: "How do we, as partners, get Joule Studio set up correctly in our environments?"

This guide is built specifically for you. It synthesizes insights from our support channels and direct partner feedback to address your most common challenges, such as multi-global account integrations and navigating the new SAP Build licensing in TDD environments. Whether you're starting fresh or integrating existing services, this post outlines everything you need to know to get started efficiently and cost-effectively.

Let's get started!

Critical Prerequisites: Licensing & Plans

Before diving into the setup flows, let's clarify three critical concepts that are often sources of confusion for partners. Getting these right from the start will save you significant time and effort.

The "New" SAP Build Plan (build-default)

Many partners have existing SAP Build entitlements on a legacy "standard" plan. To use Joule Studio, you must use the build-default plan, specifically for SAP Build Process Automation.

  • Critical Action: Do NOT order a new, separate SAP Build subscription! In your existing Partner TDD Global Account (under a PAYG model), the entitlement for the new plan is already available.
    • You simply need to navigate to the Service Marketplace in your BTP cockpit and activate the SAP Build Process Automation service, ensuring you select the build-default plan during setup.
  • Note: Ordering a new subscription instead of activating the existing entitlement often leads to selecting the wrong plan and creates unnecessary account complexity.
  • TDD Licensing Options:
    • License the Pay-As-You-Go for SAP BTP for cloud test, demo, and development (SKU 8009282). This grants you access to free "Fair Use Limits" for SAP Build (Recommended)
    • Alternative (Subscription): A subscription-based SAP Build TDD developer license (SKU 8019951) is also available, but it does not include the Fair Use Limits.
  • What is Fair Use Limits (FUL): The Fair Use Limit where the partner is provided an entitled specified threshold amount of TDD services free of charge per billing cycle. It‚Äôs designed to support development without unexpected costs.
    • Please refer to this link for more details on FUL - https://partneredge.sap.com/en/library/assets/products/tech_plat/dgl/30/23/SAP1223023.html

  Joule Entitlement 

    • TDD Joule Base SKU: 8020592
    • Joule for Consultant and Joule for Developers are different licenses and not connected with Joule Studio license and its activation.

  • For Custom Joule Skills: There is no additional cost for the orchestration and invocation of custom Joule Skills using the current features in Joule Studio. This means you do not need AI Units to run custom Joule Skills in your production environments.

  • For Custom Joule Agents: Following the promotion throughout January 2026, the execution of custom Joule Agents in production will consume AI Units.

  • It‚Äôs important to note that for both custom skills and agents, the underlying components they use will still follow their standard commercial models. For example, if your custom Joule skill or agent kicks off a business process automation, the usage of SAP Build Process Automation will still be billed according to its pricing structure.

The Multi-Global Account Scenario

It is very common for partners to have their Joule entitlement in a TDD subscription based global account and their SAP Build entitlement in a separate TDD PAYG global account. This is a supported scenario.

  • The Golden Thread: The key to making this work is to ensure that both global accounts are federated under the same SAP Cloud Identity Services (IAS). This single identity provider is what allows the two systems to trust each other and integrate seamlessly.
  • To run Joule Booster or Joule Formation (see table below), select the 2 global accounts you have.

Understanding Your Integration Flow: Starting Points and Required Steps

This table outlines the five primary scenarios for integrating SAP Build Process Automation (SBPA in the future text) capabilities into the Joule Studio environment.  Identify which flow best matches your current setup, whether you‚Äôre starting fresh or have existing SBPA or Joule subscriptions. This will immediately provide you with the exact action steps and critical notes required for a successful connection.

 

Starting Point

Key Action Steps

The partner is setting up both Joule and SBPA from scratch. 

  • Check the Prerequisites mentioned above. Verify the assignments.
  • Setup SBPA.  
    Setup SBPA Step by Step Video Guide
  • Both Joule and SBPA need to be on the same Cloud Identity Service. 
  • Connect Joule and SBPA by running the Joule Booster 
    Step by Step Video Guide for Joule Studio Activation SAP BTP
  • Verify SBPA Role Collections. (On SBPA Sub Account) 
  • Create Joule Role Collections. (On Joule Sub Account) 
    • joule_extensibility
    • end_user 
  • Finalize trust/security configurations.
  • Verify entitlement/instance setup. 
  • Access Joule Studio.

The partner already has Joule (Booster provisioned) and now links the existing SBPA (it must be a build-default plan) for Joule Studio.

  1. Verify SBPA Prerequisites: Ensure SBPA entitlement is on the build-default plan (standard plan is not compatible).
  2. Setup SBPA.  
    Setup SBPA Step by Step Video Guide
  3. Both Joule and SBPA need to be on the same Cloud Identity Service. 
  4. Update Formation in Joule Global Account:
    1. Navigate to System Landscape -> Formations. 
    2. Select the existing Integration with Joule formation.
    3. Click Include Systems and select the SBPA subaccount.
    4. Check Enable Capability Deployment and finalize. 
  5. Wait for Formation Status to become Ready. 
  6. Verify SBPA Role Collections. (On SBPA Sub Account) 
  7. Create Joule Role Collections. (On Joule Sub Account) 
    1. joule_extensibility
    2. end_user 

The partner has an existing SBPA (on the correct build-default plan) and now wants to add Joule.

  • Check the Prerequisites mentioned above for Joule. Verify the assignments.
  • Both Joule and SBPA need to be on the same Cloud Identity Service. 
  • Connect the new Joule to the existing SBPA by running the Joule Booster 
    Step by Step Video Guide for Joule Studio Activation SAP BTP
  • Verify SBPA Role Collections. (On SBPA Sub Account) 
  • Create Joule Role Collections. (On Joule Sub Account) 
    • joule_extensibility
    • end_user 
  • Finalize trust/security configurations.
  • Verify entitlement/instance setup. 
  • Access Joule Studio.

The partner already has both services (on the correct plan); they just need to be linked for Joule Studio.

  • Check the Prerequisites mentioned above. Verify the assignments.
  • Both Joule and SBPA need to be on the same Cloud Identity Service. 
  • Update Formation in Joule Global Account:
    • Navigate to System Landscape -> Formations. 
    • Select the existing Integration with Joule formation.
    • Click Include Systems and select the SBPA subaccount.
    • Check Enable Capability Deployment and finalize. 
  • Wait for Formation Status to become Ready. 
  • Verify SBPA Role Collections. (On SBPA Sub Account) 
  • Create Joule Role Collections. (On Joule Sub Account) 
    • joule_extensibility
    • end_user 

The partner has both, but SBPA is on the standard plan (requires an upgrade).

  • Upgrade SBPA to the correct plan (build-default).
  • Both Joule and SBPA need to be on the same Cloud Identity Service. 
  • Update Formation in Joule Global Account:
    • Navigate to System Landscape -> Formations. 
    • Select the existing Integration with Joule formation.
    • Click Include Systems and select the SBPA subaccount.
    • Check Enable Capability Deployment and finalize. 
  • Wait for Formation Status to become Ready. 
  • Verify SBPA Role Collections. (On SBPA Sub Account) 
  • Create Joule Role Collections. (On Joule Sub Account) 
    • joule_extensibility
    • end_user 

How to Activate the Limited-Time Offer for Agent Builder

Once you have the prerequisites in place, you can take advantage of our promotional offer to explore the full potential of custom Joule agents. Here's how:

  1. Build Your Agent: The capability to build Joule agents will automatically appear in your lobby‚Äîno extra setup required.
  2. Test & Run for Free: Activate our limited-time promotional offer to run your custom agents with zero execution costs from now throughout January, 2026.

To activate the offer:

1. Navigate to the Control Tower in your SAP Build tenant.

2. Select AI Agent Builder Activation.

3. Enable agent builder, by accepting the terms and condition

FAQ & Common Pitfalls for Partners

Q1: I don't see the build-default plan for SAP Build in my TDD account. How do I get it?   Do not order a new paid subscription. Ensure you have the correct TDD account with BTP PAYG license. Then, go to your BTP Cockpit -> Service Marketplace. Find "SAP Build Process Automation" and create a new instance/subscription, making sure to select the build-default plan.

Q2: My Joule and SAP Build are in different Global Accounts. Is that a problem?  No, this is a common and supported partner scenario. The absolute requirement is that both global accounts' subaccounts use the same Cloud Identity Service (IAS) tenant for authentication.

Q3: I ran the booster, but Joule Studio doesn't appear, or I get an error when deploying. What's wrong? This is almost always one of three issues:

  1. Mismatched Identity Services: Your Joule and SBPA subaccounts are pointing to different IAS tenants.
  2. Incorrect SBPA Plan: You are still on the "standard" plan instead of "build-default".
  3. Incorrect Joule SKU: Make sure you have a correct Joule license under Joule service TDD SKU (8018168) at no cost. To be on the safe side, please contact with your account manager, making sure you have right SKU enabled.
  4. Missing Role Collections: Your user is missing the joule_extensibility and end_user roles in the Joule subaccount, or the necessary developer roles in the SBPA subaccount.

Q4: I followed the steps, but deployment still fails with an IdP error: This points to a deeper trust configuration issue. Verify the trust settings between your BTP subaccounts and the IAS tenant. Ensure the Integration with Joule Formation status is Ready. If the issue persists, we recommend logging a free Technical Advisory request via the SAP BTP Technical Advisory service for expert assistance.

Q5: I am experiencing an ongoing issue and require further assistance. How may I contact you? Please submit a free Technical Advisory request via the SAP BTP Technical Advisory service for expert assistance.

Helpful Resources for Setup and Activation 

  • How to get started with Joule Studio
  • Provisioning Joule Studio 
  • Enabling Joule Studio for existing customers 
  • Step by Step Video Guide for Joule Studio Activation SAP BTP
  • Reference Architecture for Joule Studio 
  • Activate Joule Studio in 5 Simple Steps

entry.title: Ready, Set, Go! Jump-start complex Collaboration Scenarios with Start Forms
entry.content:
Manually creating Collaborations in SAP Integrated Product Development (IPD) often requires several steps: creating the Collaboration itself, adding Reference Objects and Participants, starting Workflows, and more. Public APIs let you automate these steps. By invoking those APIs from a Process in SAP Build Process Automation - triggered by a Start Form - you can deliver an app-like experience to users inside SAP Build Work Zone.

This post shows how to provide dedicated Start Form apps for common IPD Collaboration scenarios. The main steps are:

  • Configure the Collaboration Type.
  • Design the Process and Start Form.
  • Add the Start Form to SAP Build Work Zone.

Configure the Collaboration Type

Create a Collaboration Type that maps to your business needs. Define a Status Profile, add Reference Objects, and attach Workflows. Using APIs to create Collaborations imposes no extra requirements.

Configure Collaboration

 

Design the Process and Start Form

Make sure that you have imported all required Actions for SAP Integrated Product Development Collaboration from SAP Business Accelerator Hub. Create a new Process in SAP Build Process Automation and design a Form as Trigger for the Process.

Start Form Designer

Add the Actions you need based on the Collaboration properties you want to set. In our example:

  1. Create a new Collaboration.
  2. Add a Participant.
  3. Add a Reference Object.
  4. Optionally start a Workflow (based on a user choice).

There are no tasks that require user interaction in this example. Of course, you can use all features provided by SAP Build Process Automation.

Process Design

Add Start Form to SAP Build Work Zone

Create a local copy of the Process Trigger App and provide the Launchpad Configuration Parameters of your deployed Process. Add this to your site and apply the required authorizations. The form will become visible as separate tile.

Start Form in SAP Build Work Zone

When users click the tile, the Start Form appears. 

Start Form

After they complete required fields and submit, the Process invokes the APIs to create the Collaboration, add the Reference Object and Participant, and start the Workflow if requested. The collaboration is ready within seconds and contains all necessary data for users to begin work.

Ready to use Collaboration

Summary

Start Forms are an efficient way to expose frequently used Collaboration setups to end users. By leveraging custom Processes, you can enrich user input with external data, add validations, and improve data quality and the overall experience - enabling smoother, faster collaboration.

entry.title: Guide to Process Automation APIs - Part II - API Keys
entry.content:
In this series:

  • Guide to Process Automation APIs - Part I - Getting Started
  • Guide to Process Automation APIs - Part II - API Keys (this blog post)

API keys are required when called SAP Build Process Automation keys, but it can be confusing to know you need to provide, what different keys will return, and how to set it all up.

When do you need an API key?

Each environment lets you assign permissions to users for that environment. To do this, in the environment, click on Share.

Then you will be able to assign to a user specific authorizations. @Alex-Fortin (who is brilliant) has a wonderful blog about "shared" environments and assigning authorizations, including a table of what each authorization enables.

Different authorizations will allow you different API calls, but let's use the Workflow API as an example. If you have the Monitor authorization than you will be able to run the Workflow API for this environment.

To make it more complicated, you can also have the ProcessAutomationAdmin role collection (from the SAP BTP cockpit) and then you can run this API for any environment, without needing authorizations for any of the environments. 

And ll of this works WITHOUT ANY API KEY if you are authenticated using user token exchange. But if you are using client credentials and are authenticated simply as the service, then you need an API key. 

 

How to create an API key?

Go to the SAP Build Control Tower and click Others > API Keys. 

Then just create a new API key.

Then you set the following:

  • Name/Description
  • Scopes, that is, what authorizations assigned to the key. There is information on what each scope means 
  • Environments, that is, for which environments the key will work. You can specify one or more environments, or you can give the key access to all environments, including future ones. 

The scopes are explained in this documentation page. For reading workflow instances, you need trigger_read and environment_read scopes.

When you are finished, the key is displayed. You have one chance to copy it, and then you can no longer retrieve it from SAP Build.

Note that there is also a UI for creating API keys in each environment. The UI is the same except that that environment is automatically selected and you cannot select a different one.

 

What does API return based on the key?

If the API key is required, you must provide it as an HTTP header with the name api-key.

Note that the key used to be irpa-api-key, or something like that. I went crazy wondering why my API calls were not working, until something told me that the key name had apparently changed. üòæ

The following is a summary of what happens given the example of calling the GET call of the Workflow API's workflow-instances, depending on:

  • How you authenticate
  • What role the user has (if user token exchange is used)
  • Whether the user has the Monitor authorization for the given environment (if user token exchange is used)
  • Whether an API key is sent that is valid and has the correct scopes for the given API
ProcessAutomationAdmin Role CollectionAPI KeyMonitor AuthorizationAuthenticationDoes API return values?
‚úÖNANAUser Token Exchange‚úÖ
‚ùåNA‚úÖUser Token Exchange‚úÖ
‚ùåNA‚ùåUser Token Exchange ‚ùå
 NA ‚ùåNA Client Credentials ‚ùå 
 NA‚úÖNA Client Credentials ‚úÖ

As an example, in this call:

  • I am authenticated using client credentials.
  • A URL parameter indicates to return only workflow instances from the salesgroup environment.
  • I supplied an API key for the salesgroup environment with trigger_read and environment_read  scopes  

And now I can see the running instances for that environment.

In upcoming blogs, we'll look at specific APIs, what they return/do and how to use them.

P.S.: Apologies for taking so long on this Part II üòΩ

entry.title: SAP Joule Extensibility - With Joule Studio Skill Builder
entry.content:
During TechEd, AI was a central theme across nearly all sessions ‚Äî it was rare to find one where the term ‚ÄúAI‚Äù wasn‚Äôt mentioned. Many of these sessions focused on Joule agents, skills, and the Agent Builder, which is expected to be released by the end of December 2025.

That said, Joule Studio is already available today as part of Build Process Automation. In addition to the upcoming Agent Builder, it is currently possible to extend Joule‚Äôs capabilities using Custom Joule Skills through the Joule Skill Builder.

To put it simply, we are still running S/4HANA 2022 FPS02, and features such as Sales Order Fulfillment and Monitoring (SAP Note 3459573) via Joule are only available in later releases. As a result, asking Joule transactional questions related to Sales Orders does not yield any response.

Here‚Äôs where the Joule Skill Builder in Joule Studio comes into play.

We could create a custom skill and leverage existing BAPIs in the S/4HANA system. (First, a destination must be configured in the BPA BTP subaccount to establish the connection with the S/4 system.)

Once the S/4 system is accessible from BPA via this destination, the next step is to define actions‚Äîspecifying which fields, tasks, and data should be retrieved from S/4 using the relevant BAPIs (in this case, those related to Sales Orders).

The only mandatory input field required is the Sales Document Number; all other fields have been excluded from the selection.

The following are the only output fields (or outputs) of interest for this Joule Skill.

Once the Action is defined, we‚Äôre ready to build our first basic Joule Skill. I‚Äôll include a few numbered screenshots to illustrate the process and explain the overall flow.

 

Once the skill is deployed in your BPA environment, you can grant and share access to other users using the Share option. To test the skill, simply launch the standalone Joule using the Launch button.

The skill can also be deployed and made available to the central/shared Joule instance that is enabled across the SAP landscape, encompassing both private and public cloud systems and services (via Joule Formation).

Now we can retry the same Sales Order queries to check if Joule can provide meaningful responses. This time, I invoked Joule directly from our S/4HANA system, rather than launching it as a standalone instance from BPA.

Although this functionality is not natively supported in the S/4HANA version we are currently running, we successfully extended Joule‚Äôs capabilities by creating custom skills to address a simple, practical use case.

Disclaimer: An additional skill was also developed to demonstrate the Card with Buttons feature; however, it is not covered here üôÇ

Helpful Links

How to Get Started with Joule Studio

Set Up Joule Studio

Mission in Discovery Center

entry.title: Hands-On Guide: SAP Build + Joule Skill for Purchase Order Listing, Approval, or Modification
entry.content:
Introduction

In this tutorial, we will build an AI powered Purchase Order listing, modification or approval app using SAP Build and Joule. This step by step guide covers everything from OData integration to creating a working Joule Skill.

 

Table of Contents

  • 1. Create an Environment
  • 2. Exposing the Destination
  • 3. Create a database table to store purchase orders
  • 4. Create a CDS from the ZTABLE for Odata
  • 5. Create OData service with T-code SEGW
  • 6. Activate the Odata service via /iwfnd/maint_service T-code
  • 7. Crete an Action in SAP Build
  • 8. Create A Joule Skill to Get Purchase Order
  • 9. Create A Joule Skill to Approve Purchase Order
  • 10. Launch The Joule and Test The Skills

 

 

In today‚Äôs SAP ecosystem, intelligent automation is an expectation, not a future goal. SAP Build allows developers to quickly create business applications without extensive coding and SAP Joule brings AI-driven intelligence to these experiences.

In this hands-on guide, I‚Äôll walk you through the process of building a Joule skill that connects to an OData service, allowing users to list, approve, and update purchase orders directly through SAP Build. ( This guide uses ZTABLE to store purchase order data because the standard SAP tables in the test system I work on don't have enough or the right kind of data. However, you can use the standard tables instead of ZTABLE. )

This project shows how AI capabilities can seamlessly integrate into SAP‚Äôs low-code environment, enabling automation and human decision-making in one interface. Whether you want to enhance your workflow with intelligent actions or explore real-world Joule integration scenarios, this guide will provide a practical starting point.

 

1. Create an Environment

 

We need to create an environment for testing joule skill.

Open the SAP Build Lobby, choose Control Tower->Environments and press the Create button.

 

 

Name your environment and add Description.

 

2. Exposing the Destination

 

Url of the destination on BTP is the url of our SAP system and the destination must have these properties: 

sap.applicationdevelopment.actions.enabled -> true

sap.processautomation.enabled -> true

sap.build.usage -> odata_gen

 

Also the destination‚Äôs user will be used for set an external break-point for debugging the ABAP code.

 

 

Open the SAP Build Lobby, choose Control Tower->Destinations and press the Add button.

 

Select the Destination and choose next.

 

Choose the environment in which you want to use the target. For this tutorial you can choose the Test Environment that you create.

 

3. Create a database table to store purchase orders

@EndUserText.label : 'Purchase Order Change With Sap Build'
@AbapCatalog.enhancementCategory : #NOT_CLASSIFIED
@AbapCatalog.tableCategory : #TRANSPARENT
@AbapCatalog.deliveryClass : #A
@AbapCatalog.dataMaintenance : #ALLOWED
define table zbg_build_test {
  key mandt                      : mandt not null;
  key purchaseorder              : ebeln not null;
  key purchaseorderitem          : ebelp not null;
  key reservationitem            : ebelp not null;
  material                       : matnr;
  materialcompisvariablesized    : boolean;
  materialcomponentisphantomitem : boolean;
  reservation                    : char10;
  @Semantics.quantity.unitOfMeasure : 'zbg_build_test.entryunit'
  requiredquantity               : menge_d;
  requirementdate                : dats;
  reservationisfinallyissued     : boolean;
  baseunit                       : meins;
  @Semantics.quantity.unitOfMeasure : 'zbg_build_test.entryunit'
  quantityinentryunit            : menge_d;
  entryunit                      : meins;
  plant                          : werks_d;
  latestrequirementdate          : dats;
  billofmaterialitemnumber       : ebelp;
  bomitemcategory                : char1;
  isbulkmaterialcomponent        : boolean;
  debitcreditcode                : shkzg;
  @Semantics.quantity.unitOfMeasure : 'zbg_build_test.entryunit'
  withdrawnquantity              : menge_d;
  approver                       : uname;
  appoved                        : flag;

}

 

Fill the table:

 

 

4. Create a CDS from the ZTABLE for Odata

 

@AbapCatalog.sqlViewName: 'ZSLV_BUILD_TST_V'
@AbapCatalog.compiler.compareFilter: true
@AbapCatalog.preserveKey: true
@AccessControl.authorizationCheck: #NOT_REQUIRED
@EndUserText.label: 'Purchasing Document Informations CDS'
@Metadata.ignorePropagatedAnnotations: true
@ObjectModel.deleteEnabled: true
@ObjectModel.createEnabled: true
@ObjectModel.updateEnabled: true
define view ZSLV_V_BUILD_TEST as select from zbg_build_test as z 
    
{   @EndUserText.label: 'Purchase Order'
    key purchaseorder,
    @EndUserText.label: 'Purchase Order Item'
    key purchaseorderitem,
    @EndUserText.label: 'Reservation Item'
    key reservationitem,
    @EndUserText.label: 'Material'
    material,
    @EndUserText.label: 'Material Size'
    materialcompisvariablesized,
    @EndUserText.label: 'Material Item'
    materialcomponentisphantomitem,
    @EndUserText.label: 'Reservation'
    reservation,
    @EndUserText.label: 'Quantity'
    requiredquantity,
    @EndUserText.label: 'Date'
    requirementdate,
    @EndUserText.label: 'Reservation Issue'
    reservationisfinallyissued,
    @EndUserText.label: 'Unit'
    baseunit,
    @EndUserText.label: 'Entry Unit'
    entryunit,
    @EndUserText.label: 'Quantity In Entry Unit'
    quantityinentryunit,
    @EndUserText.label: 'Plant'
    plant,
    @EndUserText.label: 'Latest Requirement Date'
    latestrequirementdate,
    @EndUserText.label: 'Bill Of Material Number'
    billofmaterialitemnumber,
    @EndUserText.label: 'BOM Item Category'
    bomitemcategory,
    @EndUserText.label: 'Is Bulk Material'
    isbulkmaterialcomponent,
    @EndUserText.label: 'Debit Credit Code'
    debitcreditcode,
    @EndUserText.label: 'With Drawn Quantity'
    withdrawnquantity,
    @EndUserText.label: 'Approver'
    approver,
    @EndUserText.label: 'Approved'
    appoved 
    
}

 

5. Create OData service with T-code SEGW

(Because of the version of the system I work on, this guide uses SEGW instead of RAP to create an OData service. However, you can easily create your own OData service with RAP.)

Press ‚ÄòCreate Project‚Äô button, fill the fields and assign the package, request (For this tutorial it will be local object).

 

Complete the creation.

 

Extend the project, right click to ‚ÄòData Model‚Äô, select the Reference->Source

 

 

Fill the CDS name that you created. Choose ‚ÄòNext‚Äô.

 

 

Choose ‚ÄòFinish‚Äô.

 

 

Activate and generate the Service:

 

 

Go to the class ZCL_ZSLV_BUILD_DPC_EXT. At the bottom of the method list redefine the update method ZSLV_V_BUILD_TES_UPDATE_ENTITY.

 

 

In the method, update the approved field with the below code and activate it.

 

METHOD zslv_v_build_tes_update_entity.
 
  DATA: lv_ebeln TYPE ebeln,
        lv_ebelp TYPE ebelp,
        lv_item  TYPE ebelp,
        ls_entity TYPE zcl_zslv_build_mpc=>ts_zslv_v_build_testtype,
        lr_entity TYPE REF TO data,
        ls_table TYPE zbg_build_test.
 
  LOOP AT it_key_tab INTO DATA(ls_key).
    CASE ls_key-name.
      WHEN 'purchaseorder'.
        lv_ebeln = ls_key-value.
      WHEN 'purchaseorderitem'.
        lv_ebelp = ls_key-value.
      WHEN 'reservationitem'.
        lv_item = ls_key-value.
    ENDCASE.
  ENDLOOP.
 
  io_data_provider->read_entry_data( IMPORTING es_data = ls_entity ).
  MOVE-CORRESPONDING ls_entity TO ls_table.
  er_entity = ls_entity.
  UPDATE zbg_build_test FROM ls_table.
  COMMIT WORK.
 
ENDMETHOD.

 

6. Activate the Odata service via /iwfnd/maint_service T-code

 

Choose ‚ÄòAdd Service‚Äô

 

 

Select the ‚ÄòSystem Alias‚Äô, fill the ‚ÄòTechnical Service Name‚Äô and press ‚ÄòGet Services‚Äô. Select the service that you create and press ‚ÄòAdd Selected Services‚Äô.

 

 

Assign the package and continue.

 

 

We have added the service, which should appear as follows. In the ICF Nodes section, there is a button labeled "SAP Gateway Client" that provides a testing environment for the service. Press that button.

 

 

Select the HTTP method as ‚ÄòGET‚Äô. Press ‚ÄòEntitySets‚Äô to choose entity set. Choose the one that you created.

 

 

Press ‚ÄòExecute‚Äô button for testing and response should appear as follows.

 

 

7. Crete an Action in SAP Build

 

Open the SAP Build Lobby, choose Connectors->Actions and press the ‚ÄòCreate‚Äô button. Choose ‚ÄòOData Destinations‚Äô and select the Destination that we created.

 

 

Fill the Resource Path as follows and click ‚ÄòNext‚Äô.

 

 

The available methods are listed in this window. Select ‚ÄòNext‚Äô.

 

 

Fill the name and description for your action and create.

 

 

The action Purchase_Order_Action is created. Click the action and open it.

 

 

Select the methods in the OData Service.

 

 

The GET method's input has no required fields, only optional GET parameters.

 

 

Output parameters are the fields in the CDS that we created. 

 

 

Methods can be tested in the action interface. For the GET method we don‚Äôt need to fill any input parameters. Click ‚ÄòTest‚Äô button.

 

 

The data appears on the ‚ÄòTest Preview‚Äô section.

 

 

The PATCH method requires purchaseorder, purchaseorderitem and reservationitem, all of which are key fields in our ZTABLE and CDS.

 

 

There are no standard output in PATCH method.

 

 

In the Test section, all required fields and fields that need to be changed must be filled out. In this scenario these fields are purchaseorder, purchaseorderitem, reservationitem and approved fields.

 

Also the link on the Test section can be used in the SAP Gateway Client to test the PATCH method.

 

 

 

PATCH method return ‚Äú204: NO CONTENT‚Äù and empty Response. This means the update is successful and we will use this emptiness in our joule skill.

 

 

After checking and testing, save the methods using the ‚ÄòSave‚Äô button and select ‚ÄòRelease‚Äô. After the release process, the action should appear as shown below. Then, press 'Publish'.

 

 

You can debug when testing methods via the SAP Gateway Client or the SAP Build Action. Set an external breakpoint for the user in your destination that we created at the beginning.

 

 

For the PATCH method, our key fields in the internal table IT_KEY_TAB. 

 

 

8. Create A Joule Skill to Get Purchase Order

 

Open the SAP Build Lobby, choose Create->Joule Skill and fill the name and description. Open the created skill.

 

 

Select the ‚ÄôTrigger‚Äô step. On the ‚ÄòGeneral‚Äô tab fill the name and description. Allow Joule to generate a response and skill to be started directly by user.

 

 

We don't need input, but outputs can vary according to our needs. In this tutorial, the parameters shown below have been added as outputs.

Choose ‚ÄòConfigure‚Äô and add parameters you want to show to the user. For this example, all parameters are string except the ‚Äòapproved‚Äô which is boolean.

 

 

 

Press ‚Äò+‚Äô and choose ‚ÄòCall Action‚Äô, ‚ÄòBrowse All Actions‚Äô.

 

 

Search for ‚ÄòZSLV_V_BUILD_TEST‚Äô or your Service Name. Add the ‚ÄòGet entities from ZSLV_V_BUILD_TEST‚Äô.

 

 

Select the ‚ÄòDestination Variable‚Äô as Destination we created. 

 

 

We can skip the input tab because there are no input for GET method.

 

 

We can see the output parameters in this tab.

 

 

On the "End" step, we need to assign the input and output parameters for the skills. Since we don't have any inputs, let's assign the outputs added in the "Trigger" step as our action's outputs.

 

 

Save the Joule Skill.

 

 

And Release.

 

 

Now Deploy.

 

 

Choose the Environment we created and click ‚ÄòUpgrade‚Äô.

 

 

Match the destinations, and the skill will be ready to use by Joule after deployment.

 

 

9. Create A Joule Skill to Approve Purchase Order

 

On the ‚ÄòTrigger‚Äô step, fill the name and description. Deactivate the ‚ÄòAllow Joule to generate a response‚Äô feature because in this skill we will create our own messages. The other feature should be active.

 

 

Configure the input parameters. Add purchaseorder, purchaseorderitem and reservationitem key fields as string. For approve skill we don‚Äôt need any output field.

 

 

Choose ‚Äò+‚Äô and ‚ÄòCall Action‚Äô.

 

 

Browse All Actions.

 

 

Search update or the service name. Add the Update entity in ZSLV_V_BUILD_TEST.

 

 

On the ‚ÄòGeneral‚Äô tab, assign the Destination.

 

 

On the ‚ÄòInputs‚Äô tab, assign the purchaseorder, purchaseorderitem and reservationitem to the parameters created on the "Trigger" step.

 

 

We only need to fill the fields ‚Äòapproved‚Äô from the fields to be updated. We need to configure the ‚Äòapproved‚Äô field because action inputs can only be string. 

 

Choose ‚Äòapproved‚Äô field and ‚ÄòApply a formula‚Äô.

 

Type ‚Äòtrue‚Äô and click ‚ÄòApply‚Äô.

 

 

Choose ‚Äò+‚Äô and ‚ÄòCheck Condition‚Äô.

 

 

Choose the ‚ÄòCondition Editor‚Äô.

 

 

Add the following conditions and Click ‚ÄòApply‚Äô. If PATCH method is executed successfully, the result will be empty. 

 

 

If the condition is met, the left branch of the condition executes. In the opposite case, the ‚ÄòDefault‚Äô branch of the condition executes.

 

Choose the ‚Äò+‚Äô on the left branch and ‚ÄòSend Response‚Äô.

 

 

Open Message Editor.

 

 

Fill the parameters as shown below and save.

 

 

You can add parameters to the title and message with the ‚Äò<>‚Äô button.

 

 

Do the same steps for the right branch of the condition. ‚Äò+‚Äô -> ‚ÄôSend Response‚Äô -> ‚ÄòOpen Message Editor‚Äô

 

Fill the parameters as shown below and save.

 

 

Save, Release and Deploy just like the previous GET_PURCHASE_ORDER skill.

 

10. Launch The Joule and Test The Skills

 

Open the SAP Build Lobby, choose Control Tower->Environments->Joule

 

 

Launch the joule, ask for Purchase Orders and get the details.

 

 

Ask joule to approve the purchase orders and get the illustrated success message card we create.

entry.title: Tribute to Thomas Volmering
entry.content:
üì¢ Today is @thomas_volmering's last day at SAP. 

Thomas joined SAP 26 years ago, and I met him when he was head of Product Management for SAP Build Process Automation, before he became Head of Product for SAP Build. Together we worked on many communication projects for SAP Build, including technical blog posts that you can read here. üì∞

Let me just say that it has been a great pleasure and also some fun working with him, and I thank Thomas a lot for that. üôèüèª

Please join me in wishing Thomas the very best for what's to come! üëçüèª
